title: tories party shirkers not strivers
story: Boris Johnson has managed to start the year better than he ended 2021. He was right to resist further coronavirus restrictions, to decry attempts to “bowdlerise” our history following the Colston Four verdict, and to accuse anti-vaxxers of spouting “mumbo jumbo”.To some extent, the Prime Minister appears to have become reacquainted with his Tory testicles over the festive period.Yet as Jacob Rees-Mogg (another man who was seemingly gifted back his Conservative cojones for Christmas) pointed out at Cabinet this week – the biggest threat to Mr Johnson’s premiership is not Covid, nor sleaze nor even Downing Street’s wallpaper bill, but the looming cost of living crisis.Quite rightly, Mr Rees-Mogg questioned why on earth Rishi Sunak was proceeding with the planned rise in National Insurance Contributions (NIC), pushing the tax burden to its highest since Clement Attlee was prime minister after the Second World War.Even deputy Labour leader Angela Rayner couldn’t quite get her socialist tax-and-spend head around it, telling PMQs on Wednesday: “Inflation is about to hit 6 per cent … millions of British workers face a further pay cut and his Chancellor is handing them a tax hike.”The Resolution Foundation think-tank predicts the NIC rise, which comes into force in April and breaks a Tory manifesto pledge, will cost middle-earning households about £300 a year.Since returning to the office after the festive break I have been inundated with data outlining how Britons are increasingly starting to feel the pinch, with Paul Johnson, the director of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, predicting it “could well be worse than the financial crisis”. And it’s not just tax, but household bills, too.“Millions of households could be thrown onto the energy breadline without urgent targeted support from Government,” screamed one press release from Uswitch, as Mr Johnson refused to scrap VAT on utility bills.Another pointed out how the price of petrol, which was roughly £1.11 per litre before the pandemic, is now the highest it has been in a decade, with experts predicting it could hit £1.50 per litre before long.Another, from the British Chambers of Commerce, warned that 58 per cent of firms expect their prices to increase in the next three months, the highest on record. Sixty six per cent of businesses cited inflation as a concern, also a record high.Such figures are deeply worrying – but so too is the Government’s seemingly cloth-eared response to the impending crisis. Like Gordon Brown blaming everything on the “global financial crisis”, we now have an intransigent Chancellor banging on about the need to tackle the NHS backlog, as if, miraculously, a £36 billion cash injection without any actual reform will suddenly solve all the health service’s ills.To make matters worse, yesterday we learnt that more than a million people are set to be dragged into the higher rate tax band by 2026.The Treasury’s plan to freeze income tax thresholds at a time of rapid wage and price inflation will push 1.2 million workers’ earnings above the 40p mark, according to analysis by the House of Commons Library.It is frankly hard to think of a worse way of treating the hard-working backbone of Britain that voted for Mr Johnson in 2019.During the Conservative Party leadership election, he had pledged to raise the threshold at which people start paying income tax at the higher rate to £80,000.Instead, we now have aspirational middle-income families finding themselves “fiscally dragged” into tax bands originally intended for the wealthy. This is a galling move by a Government seemingly incapable of controlling its own profligacy.For millions of people, even Red Wall voters at the last election, one of the main attractions of the Conservatives was that they were a party that supposedly stood on the side of people who want to get ahead in life.Like Mrs Thatcher’s manifestos in the 1980s, theirs was an appeal to the kind of people who want to save, buy their own home, get a second car, and go on a foreign holiday. The Tories have traditionally championed hard work and enterprise. They loathed benefit cheats and long-term unemployment. They represented the kind of self-improvement, taking-setbacks-on-the-chin, and getting-on-your-bike philosophy that Love Island star Molly-Mae Hague has, predictably, been criticised by the Left for espousing. (If Mr Johnson wants to capitalise on a half decent week, he would be wise to throw his support behind her Thatcherite thinking.)Lest we forget, this was precisely how he sold the Conservatives at the last election. There would be no tax rises. They weren’t those lazy Reds in Corbyn’s Labour, who wanted to confiscate your wealth. There was a more optimistic message towards immigrants: this is the country where you can come and be whatever you want to be if you work hard enough. The points-based immigration system was designed to judge people on their talents rather than their identity. And then, of course, there was Brexit: a brave new world, where buccaneering Britain would make its own way as a global free trade leader.But what has actually happened instead? We have 1.3 million people off work, because they are self-isolating, many with a mild bout of Covid. We have once again got millions working from home, crippling the high street and local businesses.We have higher taxes on workers – and the self-employed. And we have higher taxes on entrepreneurs via increased corporation tax. Contrary to claims that our corporation tax rates will still be the lowest in the G7, in fact our effective marginal corporate tax rates are now going to be higher than that bastion of economic dynamism, France. Zut alors!Meanwhile, there has been no attempt to take on the unions, with the likes of Unison telling public sector workers they can now take 28 days off without a sick note as a result of new Covid rules. A defiant email to its 1.4 million members this week read: “Proof of sickness cannot be requested earlier than 28 days.” Nice work if you can get it.And let’s not get started on the bloated public sector itself, with yet more money being ploughed into unreformed services, much of it likely to be eaten up in wages and pensions for middle managers so inadequate they would never be hired by any private sector company.Is this really the side the Tories want to be on – the shirkers rather than the strivers?While I appreciate that there is a pandemic-sized hole in the public finances, how does the Government expect businesses to pay their workers higher wages if they are contending with the effects of higher inflation themselves?Moreover, what possible incentive is there for employees to earn more money, if they are going to end up being taxed by stealth?The “fiscal drag” research suggests that this isn’t just going to affect high earners. An extra 1.2 million are expected to be pushed into the 40p tax band that starts at £50,070, than if the Government were to raise that threshold in line with forecast inflation to £56,270. But an extra 1.5 million low paid earners will also be pushed into the 20p basic tax rate that starts at £12,570, than if the personal allowance threshold rose in line with forecast inflation to £14,070 over the next four years. Such a freeze will collectively cost families in England, Wales and Northern Ireland £11 billion by 2026 – that’s an extra £430 for the average household.This isn’t just a betrayal of the electorate – but of Conservatism itself.More from NewsPatients &#39watching Netflix box sets in ambulances&#39 as NHS delays mountInept Government decisions are the real root cause of our problemsAustralian tennis chief praises staff for &#39unbelievable job&#39 despite Novak Djokovic visa sagaRecord numbers of Cubans attempting Florida crossing as decline acceleratesMinisters warned cladding reforms are &#39not enough&#39 to end anxiety for homeownersIsraelis flock to clinics for fourth jab as hesitant UK experts say another dose is &#39not necessary&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: submarines collide far often think going get worse
story: “Submarines are no longer undersea warships,” a naval officer once told me. “They are little bubbles of GCHQ sneaking undetected around the world.” Well, perhaps not always undetected. This week, it was revealed that a Russian submarine collided in 2020 with a British warship’s sonar – a cable hundreds of metres long containing listening devices – while tracking its movements in the North Atlantic. The equipment was so damaged, the ship had to abort its 48-hour mission and return to port. A Navy source told The  that the noise made by the collision would have been so powerful that officers “probably would have scared themselves s***less”.We know about the incident because a TV crew was filming on board HMS Northumberland, the damaged boat, at the time. It begs the question: do such collisions happen regularly – we just never get to see them through a camera lens?The answer is both yes and no. While collisions are considered to be vanishingly rare, submarines (also known as ‘boats’ in naval circles) do come into regular close contact with one another – and there’s a sense that it’s becoming ever more frequent. Dive beneath the surface of our seas and it’s as though the Cold War never really ended. “We are as busy now as we’ve ever been,” one source told me. “It’s a constant game of cat and mouse.”That’s certainly how it feels to the men and women out there every day, in Royal Navy ships and Royal Air Force aircraft that spend their days hunting for submarines that lurk beneath. They search for telltale signs of human activity under the waves, or loiter on the seabed outside hostile ports, logging the inidual signatures of foreign warships to be referenced at later dates, perhaps in less peaceful times. “Russia has always been about submarines,” says a naval source, “it’s their thing”.To an extent, the rules of this cat-and-mouse game haven’t changed. Russia wants desperately to locate the British Vanguard-class submarine, one of which has been on patrol every hour for over 50 years, carrying Britain’s nuclear deterrent. Exactly where the boat is at any moment is one of the most closely guarded national secrets. The Government will also never say how many of the 16 tubes on board house a Trident II D5 nuclear missile, each with multiple 475-kiloton warheads (for comparison, Hiroshima was destroyed with a 12-kiloton bomb). However, the frequency of missions has changed markedly in recent years, with 2019 seeing the highest recorded Russian activity in the North Atlantic for over 30 years. And so too has the perceived aim of the activity. Where once Russia sent out its subs to find Nato’s nuclear-armed boats and threaten Armageddon themselves, now one of the primary goals appears to be hunting a very modern invention. The internet cable.Half a million miles of fibre-optic cables thread across the world’s ocean beds, carrying 97 per cent of global digital communications. Each strand of fibre inside the cables can carry up to 400GB of data per second, or around 375 million phone calls. Around 15 million financial transactions – worth $10 trillion – rely on the cables each day.In short, Britain’s economic prosperity and reputation as a major global finance centre depends on those cables. Prior to his appointment as Chancellor, Rishi Sunak wrote a paper for Policy Exchange titled ‘Undersea Cables – indispensable, insecure’. In it, he warned how disruption could lead to economic chaos and possibly civil unrest. “A successful attack on the UK’s undersea cable infrastructure would be an existential threat to our security,” the paper declared. It said that the cables represent “a singularly attractive target for our enemies”.Perhaps it’s little wonder, then, that Russian submarines have been “aggressively operating” around subsea cables for years. Reports in 2020 suggested Russian agents had been sent to Ireland to inspect the vulnerability of transatlantic fibres where they come ashore. As Tom Sharpe, a former Royal Navy commander and anti-submarine warfare specialist, says: “As long as the requirement to protect critical national infrastructure underwater remains, then the need to be able to detect and deter adversary submarine activity will remain.” He speculates that Russian mini-submarines may even have placed explosive charges on the cable network already, to be detonated “come the day of the race”.Technological advances are making the undersea problem more acute. Admiral Sir Tony Radakin, the Chief of the Defence Staff, says Russian submarines are getting “quieter, more capable and harder to detect”. Sources point to the new Yasen-class boats (“spectacular,” says one expert), and the small diesel electric Kilo-class submarines, which are capable of operating in much shallower waters (“tiny little Ferraris,” says another), as emerging threats. Like their western counterparts, these so-called ‘hunter-killer’ submarines do not carry nuclear weapons but are designed to hunt other submarines, or launch conventional missiles or cyber attacks against enemy targets.And then there’s the sheer proliferation of submarines around the world. China (which already has 59 submarines, although many are old), Iran (which has 17) and North Korea (71) are all believed to be developing modern boats. “The Chinese in particular are building them at a rate of knots,” says Sharpe. “How long before they send one round to the North Atlantic to take a look and prove that capability? Maybe they already have.”With such congested seas, it may seem surprising that physical collisions don’t happen more often. This is part of the game: submarines are extremely hard to detect and will do almost anything to avoid revealing their position. However, this also means they have little idea what is around them, or on top of them (hence why a source told The  that the HMS Northumberland incident was not a purposeful move by the Russians). Their ability to navigate isn’t helped by the fact that they will never emit a sonar ‘ping’ in an attempt to locate another vessel, as the sound would make them immediately obvious to anyone in the area or detectable to underwater acoustic sensor arrays located on the seabed. The ocean may be huge, but when you’re swimming blind, accidents will happen eventually.For the ships that sit on the ocean surface, it’s a slightly different challenge. They will occasionally ‘ping’ as their position is much easier to determine anyway, so they give less away by doing so. If a ‘ping’ locates a submarine, the ship can manoeuvre to stay outside weapon range. Sting-Ray Torpedoes or Mark11 Depth Charges fired from a frigate’s Merlin helicopter would then target the submarine. Ultimately, as Ali Kefford, a submarine warfare expert, puts it, “submarines are very much a political weapon, as well as a military one.” The cat and mouse games continue, day and night, in all weathers. Letting the other side know they’ve been found, as they try to maximise potential future advantages.“We are brothers and sisters. There’s a massive feeling of community. It doesn’t matter what nation you’re from.”More from NewsPatients &#39watching Netflix box sets in ambulances&#39 as NHS delays mountInept Government decisions are the real root cause of our problemsAustralian tennis chief praises staff for &#39unbelievable job&#39 despite Novak Djokovic visa sagaRecord numbers of Cubans attempting Florida crossing as decline acceleratesMinisters warned cladding reforms are &#39not enough&#39 to end anxiety for homeownersIsraelis flock to clinics for fourth jab as hesitant UK experts say another dose is &#39not necessary&#39More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

news four-ways-make-your-christmas-"Coronavirus in numbers: UK records , new casesAdvertorialByNatasha YoungCommercial Audience Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Jan Those long-awaited Christmas get-togethers with family and friends are just around the corner, but with the highly transmissible Omicron iant spreading fast it’s important to take some extra steps to make your celebrations Covid-safe. Close contact with others – especially in unventilated spaces – increases your chances of spreading Covid-. If you’re spending the festive season with loved ones there are lots of ways you can reduce the risk, including taking regular rapid lateral flow tests, letting fresh air in and getting your booster. GP Dr Claire Ashley provides some simple tips for staying safe so you and those close to you can gather round the table and enjoy your Christmas fun. Take those tests  Meeting up with loved ones  You should all do a rapid lateral flow test before you mingle.They’re free, easy to do at home and the results show in half an hour – to order a pack, go to nhs.uk get-tested.“If you haven’t got any symptoms, rapid lateral flow tests are very good at picking up Covid-,” says Dr Ashley, based in the South West. “On Christmas morning, before granny comes over for lunch, taking a test is the best way to check you’re not infectious. “My family will all have a rapid lateral flow test the morning we travel down to see my parents, andanything comes back positive, or any of us has symptoms, we won’t go. “I’m aware our plans might be disrupted. It’s not perfect, especially after last year, but I’d rather everyone stays safe.”  As Dr Ashley points out, rapid lateral flow tests are designed to pick up Covid- cases with no symptoms, soyou do have symptoms such as a fever, cough or loss of sense of taste or smell, you need to isolate immediately and take a PCR test. Andyour rapid lateral flow test does show a positive result, you’ll need to isolate and only leave the house to take a PCR test to confirm it.If you have been in contact with someone with Covid- and are double vaccinated, you should take a daily rapid lateral flow test for seven daysyou have no symptoms. If you test positive or develop symptoms in those seven days, you must self-isolate, take a PCR test and follow the guidance on gov.uk.If you are unvaccinated, you must self-isolate for  daysyou are in contact with someone who has Covid-.Don’t forget the NHS COVID- app is still the fastest way to knowyou’ve been exposed to someone who’s tested positive, so keep it on.Open the window sLetting fresh air into your home is one way to help reduce the spread of Covid-. Opening windows and doors for just  minutes will help. “Covid- is an airborne virus and the research suggests that when you’re in a well-ventilated space the risk of contracting it is reduced,” says Dr Ashley. “That’s why being outdoors is much more safe, but that’s tricky when it’s very cold. Soyou want to reduce the chances of Covid- being passed on, have the windows open so you get as much airflow as possible.” Wear a face covering You must wear a face covering in public areas such as shops, places of worship, entertainment venues, and on public transport. It’s wise to wear a mask in crowded or enclosed spaces, eventhey’re not legally required. “Face coverings are really effective at reducing how much you’re spreading Covid-,” explains Dr Ashley. Get your booster Every adult in the country now needs to get a Covid- booster vaccine, because two doses does not give you enough protection against catching Omicron. Book yours now at nhs.uk covidvaccination.Get Boosted Now is the national mission to build a wall of defence against the Omicron iant. This mission is more urgent than ever before with Covid- because Omicron is spreading fast. Vaccines are the best way we can protect ourselves. You can get a Covid- booster  weeks after your second dose. Boosters give you the best possible protection against the virus and should signicantly reduce your risk of serious illness and hospitalisation.If you haven’t had your first or second vaccine, go to nhs.uk covidvaccination or call  to book it, or find your nearest walk-in centre.“It’s also very important for pregnant women to get vaccinated,” adds Dr Ashley. “The benefits of being vaccinated and boosted really outweigh the risks.”People with lower immune systems might need to be more careful about socialising this Christmas, as they could have less protection against getting severely ill with Covid-. This includes people who are taking medication that suppresses the immune system – eg, for rheumatoid arthritis – and those having chemotherapy. For more advice on celebrating the festive season safely, visit: gov.uk coronavirus Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CoronavirusMost ReadRecommended

news politics -key-things-know-lateral-"Covid: New iant discovered in FranceByLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments Lateral flow tests are used by people who donapost have symptoms of Covid and can root out those who are asymptomatic and at danger of spreading the virus - hereaposs everything you need to know about them.The Prime Minister has refused to bring in new restrictions to tackle the surge of Omicron cases but instead is urging people to get the booster jab and get tested. Boris Johnson is sticking to Plan B measures which means people are being expected to take a testthey have been in close contact with anyone who tests positive for the virus.The quickest and easiest way to checkyou have the virus is to take a lateral flow test.Dr Nathan, an AE doctor in London at @expedition_doctor, said the three biggest mistakes are failing to spot positives, not reading the instructions, and mixing up the best way to conduct the test.He warned: “Any positive line within  minutes, evenit is so faint that it is barely visible, equals a positive result. “However,a faint line appears after  minutes, this can be ignored.” Hereaposs important things you need to know about lateral flow test and what you should doyou give a positive result.  Where can you get a lateral flow test  The best place to start is to find outyou are able to get lateral flow tests through your workplace, school or university.However, this option wonapost be available to everyone, in which case they can be ordered from the NHS website.Usually these lateral flow tests will be delivered to your home in a matter of days but there is currently shortage due to demand.  How much do the tests costs  Luckily, the tests are generally free for all purposes apart from travel. You can also go and collect them in person at pharmacies like Boots or Lloyds, as well as some community centres. Getting tests in this way is also usually free. A pack has seven tests, one for each day of the week. And, in some cases, you will be able to get two packs at once.  Is taking a test safe  According to health chiefs and medical experts, misinformation about lateral flow tests is re. Despite the risk of slight discomfort in your nasal passage, there is no risk to your brain when conducting a test.Along the same lines, misinformation spread on Facebook after a live video broadcast ly suggested ethylene oxide-coated swabs in lateral flow tests cause cancer.The Department for Health and Social care has addressed claims that Covid- tests pose a danger to humans. It told Reuters: Lateral flow tests have been rigorously tested and are safe to use on a regular basis. Any suggestion otherwise is inaccurate and harmful misinformation. Ethylene oxide is only used in the sterilisation of swabs and it is one of the most commonly used sterilisation tools in the healthcare industry, principally applied by manufacturers to keep medical devices safe. How to do a lateral flow test Before you take the test, you should blow your nose and wash your hands thoroughly. You need to put the swab about .cm into your nostril, and roll it around slowly for around  seconds. It will be easieryou continue to breathe through your nose while youaposre doing this. Some lateral flow tests are for your throat - in this case you need to swab your tonsils on both sides for around  seconds. Be careful not to touch the fabric of the swab once you have taken it out your nose or mouth. The test comes with liquid in a packet - you need to squeeze this into the small vial provided. You then need to put the swab into the vial - fabric end first - and press it firmly into the liquid while rotating it around  times. You can then dispose of the swab. You will have a nozzle cap for the vial - put this on tightly, and then carefully squeeze out two drops onto the specimen strip. Put this on a flat surface.  How long do you wait for a result You should wait for  minutes. Your results will appear - two linesit is positive, one line on the topitaposs negative, or one line on the bottomthe test is invalid.The lines may be faint - butthere are two, it means that you likely have coronavirus.What do you do with the test after Whether your Covid test is positive or negative, they should all be placed in the general waste bin. First place all the used items in the plastic pouch provided in the kit. The government website explains thatyou’re doing a home rapid lateral flow test, you should dispose of the used rapid lateral flow kit in your waste bin at home or at work. Used test kit items could include the:swab test strip sachet extraction tubeAccording to health chiefs and medical experts, misinformation about lateral flow tests is re. Despite the risk of slight discomfort in your nasal passage, there is no risk to your brain when conducting a test.  What to doyou test positive If you test positive for coronavirus you will need to self isolate immediately. This means you will need to stay at home for the duration of the self-isolation period. If you have one of the following three symptoms you will self isolate and take a PCR test. The result of this test will determine whether or not you need to continue isolating or are free to go out again as usual. The three NHS-defined symptoms are:a high temperature a new, continuous cough a loss or change to your sense of smell or tasteYou will also need to self isolateyou are contacted by Test and Trace, unless you are exempt, which includes people who have been vaccinated. If you need to self isolate and do not you could be handed a fine. If you test positive anyone who lives with you will have to self isolate also. However, there are major exemptions to this rule including vaccinated people. People aged over  years and six months who are not fully vaccinated will need to self isolate. news politics labour-mp-jack-dromeys-incredible-"Jack Dromey: Labour MP dies aged ByBenjamin LynchSEO Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsLabour MP for Birmingham Erdington Jack Dromey passed away on Friday at the age of .He began representing the long-considered safe Labour seat in  and secured a majority of , in . Dromey, along with fellow MP and we Harriet Harman, was a well-known figure in the House of Commons.Labour leader Keir Starmer said: The proud son of Irish parents, Jack Dromey dedicated his le to standing up for working people through the Labour movement, becoming Deputy General Secretary of the UK’s largest trade union and then a Labour MP.One of the ministeraposs final acts as an MP was to participate in the debate on the resettlement of Afghan refugees only a day before his death. Jack was recognised for his determination to stand up for his constituents and he was highly respected and warmly regarded across Parliament, said Starmer My thoughts and those of the whole Labour movement are with Harriet, their children and all those who knew and loved Jack. Who was MP Jack Dromey   Born in , Jack Dromey was an MP for the Birmingham Erdington constituency, first elected in . Before being elected as an MP, Dromey was an old school Labourite, working as a trade unionist. He held a senior role as Deputy General Secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, which later became known as Unite.  Dromey held a range of shadow ministerial positions, such as Shadow Minister for Housing, as well as policing, labour, pensions and paymaster general. The latest reshuffle by Labour leader Keir Stamer saw Dromey move to Shadow Minister for Immigration. Deputy Labour leader Angela Rayner said: Jack Dromey was a great mentor and supporter to me but above all a friend for many years. This is absolutely tragic news for his family, his constituents and the party. I am thinking of Harriet and the rest of his family. He will be greatly missed. What did Jack Dromey die of Labour MP Jack Dromey is understood to have passed away from natural causes. His son Joe tweeted: Our dad - Jack - died suddenly today. We loved him so, so much. Rest in peace big man x.  A statement issued on behalf of the family said: He had been a dedicated member of parliament for Birmingham Erdington since . He was a much loved husband, father and grandfather, and he will be greatly missed. Jack Dromeyaposs family  The Birmingham Erdington MP is survived by his we and fellow MP Harriet Harman and their three children, Harry, Joseph and Amy.Harman announced last month that she would be standing down at the next election.The MP for Camberwell and Peckham is one of the Labour partyaposs most recognisable faces, serving as deputy leader between  to  and is the Commonsapos recognised Mother of the House.  The two are reported to have met in  on the picket line for the strike by workers of the Grunwick film processing laboratory in London. The pair then married in . Grunwick strikers were mainly workers of South Asian origin and became signicant as a landmark strike that brought attention to ethnic minority workers in the UK.Dromey wrote about the importance of the strike for the Mirror in .Jack Dromey is survived by his we Harriet, sons Harry and Joe and daughter Amy. title: liz truss accused hiding truth
story: Exclusive: Liz Truss accused of hiding the truth over missing £, food and drink bill in TokyoThe Cabinet minister has been accused of hiding the truth after the Department for International Trade failed to highlight her team splashed more than £, on a three-night tripLiz Truss is now the Foreign Secretary Image: Tayfun Salci ZUMA Press Wire REX ShutterstockByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsForeign Secretary Liz Truss has been accused of “hiding the truth” as more revelations emerged about her expensive tastes in dining. Ms Truss failed to disclose £,. of public money spent on fancy meals and drinks whilst on a three night trip to Tokyo in . The then-Trade Secretary flew to Japan between - October  to sign Britain’s first post-Brexit trade agreement. After the trip, the Department for International Tradeclaimed her travelling party had spent £. of public money on food and drinks, in response to a Parliamentary Question posed by Labouraposs Emily Thornberry. But two months after Ms Thornberry put in an FOI request, DIT was forced to reveal she had splashed an eye-watering £,. whilst away with three officials. Last night foreign office sources suggested that Ms Truss and her team had not been able to leave her accommodation as a result of Covid rules in Tokyo. But they were unable to say how they had accrued the expenses, or whether they stayed in a hotel with its own bars and restaurants.  The Mirror understands that it is usual practice for ministers to use their expenses on foreign trips to cover the cost of meals and drinks, including bills paid for by officials at the time. Shadow Attorney General Ms Thornberry told the Mirror: “There is a clear pattern of behaviour emerging here with Liz Truss, which raises serious questions about her character. “Becauseher instinct is to hide the truth and hope that no one asks questions even over these expenses claims, what  is she willing to do that about ” It is not the first time Ms Trussapos department has failed to correctly disclose the correct amount of public money she has spent on fancy meals. After her visit to Japan, Ms Truss spent four nights in Vietnam and Singapore to sign more post-Brexit trade deals with four members of staff. The DIT initially claimed Ms Trussaposs travelling party had not spent anything on meals and drinks. But then Trade Minister Greg Hands was forced to reveal the travelling party had actually splashed £,, the equivalent of around £, per head, or £ per night.  Mr Hands also revealed Ms Truss’s travelling party spent an eye-watering £,. on accommodation in addition to the meals. “How did they go from saying there were no subsistence expenses at all, to saying the travelling party incurred expenses of £, per head, equivalent to £ per night ” Ms Thornberry questioned. A DIT spokesperson said: “This expense was initially published incorrectly due to an administrative error and subsequently corrected. All DIT expenditure is published routinely in full. “The purpose of this trip was to sign a free trade agreement with Japan covering billions of pounds of trade, supporting jobs and growth across the United Kingdom.”It comes days after it was revealed Ms Truss hosted a lunch at an expensive private club owned by a Tory donor, after overruling civil service advice to look for a cheaper venue. Leaked correspondence, first published in the Sunday Times, revealed the ex-Trade secretary “refused to consider anywhere” but  Hertford Street for a meeting with Joe Biden ’s trade representative in August last year.Ms Truss is reported to have previously used the  Hertford Street club to host “fizz with Lizz” dinners with MPs and “biz for Liz” receptions with potential donors, in preparation for a likely leadership bid.The club is considered to be London’s most exclusive club, having hosted Prince Harry ’s first date with Meghan. Ms Truss is widely seen as a favourite to become Prime MinisterBoris Johnson is ousted.The government has been contacted for comment. title: the divide between entitled rich
story: The ide between the entitled rich and the rest of us is now gaping chasmBrian Reade laments that the separation between the classes in Britain is greater than its ever beenGhislaine Maxwell is facing a long stint behind bars Image: Getty ImagesopinionByBrian Reade:,  Jan For deluded fools who believe they might be in for a prosperous year, here’s some advice.Ring up The Chase or put your grandad’s pocket watch on eBay because with the energy and tax rises coming down the line there’s a good chance you’ll be humming Buddy Can You Spare A Dime  by Easter.Some will hum a dferent tune, of course. Major shareholders in the energy firms will amass billions out of rising prices and the NI tax hike won’t hurt too many millionaire Cabinet ministers or company bosses. In fact, according to the High Pay Centre, by am today the average chief executive of a FTSE  company had already been paid the average British worker’s salary for . And he’s probably still skiing in the Alps. There’s always been a gap between the rich and the rest, but it feels like it’s becoming a chasm. And the main dference between the top % and everyone  is their expectation to be treated dferently.  Think back to the Mirror’s revelations of how Downing Street held festive knees-ups after barring the rest of us from having a cuppa with a lonely old relative. They were angered that it was even a story – as though it was a given that they were free to act dferently. Look at the Establishment attitude to the loaded heiress Ghislaine Maxwell being convicted of facilitating and participating in the sexual abuse of children. Her brother went on BBC Radio’s Today show to denigrate the jury’s verdict and tug on our heartstrings. Others sought to evoke sympathy for her by writing in newspapers about this charming woman who had been manipulated by the monster Jeffrey Epstein. If the paedophile-enabler had been a single mum on benefits, not a well-connected socialite, what are the chances of the BBC inviting her brother on to its flagship news show to plead her innocence  In the same case, we’ve seen Prince Andrew’s lawyers attempt to hide behind a silencing deal between Epstein and the woman who accuses him of sexual abuseto escape answering questions. And his family goes along with this stonewalling without being called out. Well they’re royal, ain’t they  Which brings us to the honours they dish out, most of which are bought. Sure, little people are thrown the odd bangle to disguise the charade, but the major gongs are status symbols the amoral rich seek out to show they are a cut above the rest. Last week, I named -year-old Folajimi Olubunmi-Adewole, who died in the Thames trying to rescue a drowning woman, as my Man of the Year. He didn’t make the New Year’s Honours list.  Tony Blair was knighted though, despite the Chilcot report stating he knowingly misled the country into a war which cost the lives of hundreds of thousands of Iraqis and  Britons. A petition to cancel his knighthood is climbing towards the one million that marched through London begging him to rethink his illegal invasion. But the man who has now made £million since leaving office will once again ignore it because that’s what the very rich do. That’s the power their wealth has bought. Chew on that in a couple of months when people you know are choosing whether to go further into debt with Scottish Power, or eat. title: 5 towns vanish englands worst
story: Five towns vanish from Englands worst places to live list as new places rise to topThis year’s list of Englands "worst towns" saw a substantial sht in the top picks, with Hull, Wakefield, Torquay and Halax all moving out of the top tenHull was described by one local as a a living hell for decent folk Image: UIG via Getty ImagesByAlice Peacock:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThe polling has closed for the  list of Englandaposs worst places to live - and five of last yearaposs least popular places have managed to make their way out of the top ten.The tongue-in-cheek list, which is compiled after residents have the chance to vote for their own hometowns, broke records for , with , locals voting for their own communities. The submissions also see locals offer an insight on what itaposs really like to live there, citing factors like “endless rain” and shocking hygiene as reasons that should deter people from moving there.This year’s poll saw a substantial sht in the places that received the most votes for the “worst place”, with Hull, Wakefield, Torquay and Halax all rising in popularity to make their way out of the top ten. They were replaced by Bolton, Corby, Slough and Aylesbury, which shot up from its  ranking of th worst town, to receive the most votes for the least popular place to live. Hull, which last year was ranked th worst in the charts, made a jump to th place. While the move suggested a rise in popularity, one voter still went as far as to describe the town as a living hell for decent folk. Last yearaposs th place ranking, Wakefield, didnapost appear in this yearaposs list of Englandaposs top  worst towns at all. It was unclear whether this was due to improved living conditions, or whether the residents were simply too down in the dumps to vote at all. Torquay, which last year was crowned Englandaposs th worst place to live had this year received relatively less votes for the worst place, moving to rd place. It had earned a rather ineloquent review from one local as The English Sh*tty Area. And Halax had also happily vanished from the  list of Englandaposs top  worst towns, despite being ranked the th least desirable place to live in . This year the poll, compiled by iLivehere, found a new winner as Peterborough managed to drop to number five after three glorious years of taking the crown. Aylesbury in Buckinghamshire instead took the top spot, after scoring  per cent more votes than runner-up Huddersfield. Despite Peterboroughaposs reign being over, residents are still offered up some travel advice for anyone considering a visit. They claimed: It is customarya stranger holds eye contact with you for more than three seconds, to shout “WHAT”    and become extremely aggressive.  Discussing Aylesbury, locals said the traffic jams in the town are part of the magnicent beauty of the area and all part of the tour. They said: As you enter into Aylesbury, you find yourself in a traffic jam. Don’t worry, it’s all part of the tour. Being stuck in the traffic allows you to observe the magnicent beauty of all the ‘trashy citizens’ that live there. Huddersfield came in second place after scoring more votes than half the towns on the list.  One resident claimed: Not all of Huddersfield is bad… just % of it. Another resident last year made equally cutting comments about the town, saying: Huddersfield should be avoided by all those who desire to keep their wallets, mobile phones and most of all their sense of smell. Climbing a massive  notches on the list and sliding into the top  at number six is Bolton - which pollsters called the Mancunian dingleberry. One contributor admitted there are much worse places in Britain, but claimed the seemingly endless rain only strengthens feeling of sadness [...] and pointlessness of this place.  Another made a quip about the townaposs takeaway industry, claiming restaurants there have reached the lofty heights of ONE star for hygiene. The two non-movers in this yearaposs list were Huddersfield, Jaywick in Essex, an area described as making even the worst parts of Blackpool seem like paradise, according to voters.One said: There’s a reason why Ross Kemp visited what he dubbed as ‘Britain’s toughest seaside resortapos.  Satellite town Slough made its top  debut this year, coming in at number nine. A poetry fan recalled the words of poet John Betjeman, who famously urged bombs to rain down on the town. They wrote: John Betjeman had the right idea. But not even in his wildest nightmares could he envisage the gold-plated, Currys Superstore-plagued, professional Ali G-bedevilled monster that Slough would become. title: cctv footage shows cyclist towpath
story: CCTV footage shows cyclist on towpath shortly before body was found in canalPolice are investigating after cyclist Paul Morris was found dead in a Birmingham canal and have released CCTV footage of him moments beforehand as they appeal for informationPaul Morris was seen riding his bike shortly before his body was discovered in the canal Image: BPM MEDIAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan | commentsFootage of a cyclist moments before he was was found dead in a Birmingham canal has been released by police as they appeal for information. Paul Morris was seen riding his bike shortly before his body was discovered in the waterway off Ladywood Middleway at around .pm on Tuesday, December .Images released by West Midlands Police show the -year-old man cycling along the canal towpath.Alongside the video above, police urged anyone with information to come forward to help provide his family the answers they need. His death is currently being treated as aposunexplainedapos following an inconclusive post mortem, officers said.  We’re appealing for information after the body of a man was sadly found in a canal in Birmingham last month, police stated. The body of Paul Morris was discovered at around .pm on Tuesday  December, at the junction of Ledsam Street and Ladywood Middleway. The -year-old was seen riding his bike along the canal towpath shortly before this time. There is nothing to suggest there is any foul play involved in his death, Detective Inspector Ade George pointed out and police are just trying to establish what took place. He added: “Our thoughts are with Mr Morris’ family at this really sad time. “There is nothing to suggest there was any foul play involved in his death, however we want to understand exactly what happened and to give his family the answers they need. “There is very little CCTV along this stretch of the canal so I’m asking for anyone who was around the area between pm and pm on the evening, to get in touch.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON West Midlands PoliceCCTVCCTV footage" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news cctv-shows-moment-teenager-lured-"Moment teen is attacked while thinking he was meeting girl for dateByHollie BoneNews ReporterBeth Cruse:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThis is the terrying moment a teenager who thought he was meeting a girl for a date was instead stabbed in a vicious revenge attack. The -year-old boy was stabbed in February last year after he was lured out by Snapchat message he thought were from a girl wanting to meet up, Bristol Live reports. But when he arrived at the meeting point in Fishponds, Bristol, he was kned nine times and left for dead by two  year olds in what is described as a revenge attack.The two teenagers, who have since turned  and cannot be named because of their age, were sentenced to youth custody in Bristol Crown Court on Friday.A -year-old male, who stabbed the victim, pleaded guilty to causing grievous bodily harm ahead of a trial in November, while a female was found guilty of the same offence by jurors, BristolLive reported.During her trial, the jury were told the victim was part of a rival group within Bristol and was deliberately lured to the Ridgeway Road area that night so he could be attacked. The male received a four-year sentence and the female three years.  Judge Michael Longman described the attack as co-ordinated and done with the intention of causing very serious injuries. Detective Inspector Roger Doxsey said: “This was a vicious and calculated attack on a then -year-old boy. He was mercilessly chased and stabbed approximately nine times and left for dead. “Described in court as a ‘Snapchat honey trap’, the female lured the victim to a park in Fishponds on the understanding that they were having a date, whereupon he was set upon by a number of males with knives.  “After the attack the male offender sent a ‘mic drop emoji’ with his face on via Snapchat to the female offender. His emoji meant ‘job done’ and shows the true intent behind the crime. “The victim was in intensive care but has thankfully made a steady recovery from his multiple injuries. He bravely gave evidence and we are grateful for his and his family’s support.”Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CCTVCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtCrimeTeenagersKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: couple staying yorkshires most complained
story: Couple staying at Yorkshires most complained about hotel have best time everThe Grand Hotel Scarborough has received a slew of negative reviews in recent years, including from customers who claimed they were unable to stay the night - but some guests have been full of praiseKatie Fox, , and Tony Rewcastle, , visited The Grand on New Years Eve Image: examinerliveByAmber OConnor:,  Jan | commentsA couple who visited a much-complained about Yorkshire hotel which has been labelled a “complete dump” have revealed they were pleasantly surprised by a New Year’s Eve stay.The Grand Hotel Scarborough has received a slew of negative reviews in recent years, including from customers who claimed they were unable to stay the night due to their room being “dirty” and lacking a working door.However, a couple have told how they had the best time ever there, following the hotelaposs recent refurbishment. Katie Fox, , and Tony Rewcastle, , visited The Grand on New Yearaposs Eve after spotting there were rooms available for just £.The pair did not have high expectations after being left unimpressed by a visit during the summer, Katie toldYorkshire Live.But they ended up having a great time, despite only visiting as a joke, according to the holidaymaker. We noticed straight away that they had refurbished, said Katie, who then quipped: Theyaposd got a new carpet. It didnapost smell like an old personaposs home anymore.  And the pair stayed in a new, refurbished room, which Katie thought was a lot better than it was before. She admitted she was surprised to find they had the best time ever. The couple celebrated the evening with a stroll along the beach, where they stopped for fish and chips, before heading back to the hotel to join in the festivities with the other guests. And the fun didnapost stop there. The pair then took to the hotelaposs balcony where they had a perfect birdaposs-eye view of the two firework displays which were set off on the beach. It was absolutely gorgeous, said Katie. She added: And there was a good atmosphere in the lobby. People were having fun they had music on, and there were kids running around with streamers and confetti.  Katie also praised the nice little touches made by staff: Theyaposd put a little chocolate bar in our room, all the hot drinks were in a bag sterilised, there was a little note saying happy new year, and they did free haggis at midnight. She concluded by recommending the hotel to anyone looking for a romantic New Yearaposs Eve, or just hoping to visit Scarborough. Katie said: My opinion of The Grand is they are doing things to change, and we genuinely enjoyed it. It is our go-to place nowwe go back to Scarborough. Previously, the hotel has responded to online critics leaving negative reviews. In response to one complaint, a spokesperson for the hotel said they were truly sorry adding: We hope you raised the concerns at the time giving us the opportunity to get it resolved during your stay. news uk-news covid-become-very-similar-common-"Covid: One in  estimated to have had virus in last weekBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A leading doctor believes coronavirus will soon resemble a common cold and thinks Omicron could be the beginning of the end of the pandemic. The University of Warwickaposs Dr Mike Tildesley believes the world will soon learn toagain as normal. The medic, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Modelling group which feeds into SAGE, previously questioned the need for curbs.He raised hopes that cases are starting to slow in Covid hot-spot London despite the UK reporting nearly , new cases on Friday.Dr Tildesley pointed to the capitalaposs flatlining cases and hospital admissions as an encouraging sign that things are starting to turn around.  He told Times Radio: The thing that might happen in the future is you may see the emergence of a new iant that is less severe, and ultimately, in the long term, what happens is Covid becomes endemic and you have a less severe version. Itaposs very similar to the common cold that weaposve lived with for many years. Weaposre not quite there yet but possibly Omicron is the first ray of light there that suggests that may happen in the longer term - it is, of course, much more transmissible than Delta was, which is concerning, but much less severe. Hopefully, as we move more towards the spring and we see the back of Omicron, we can get more inter-relationship of living with Covid as an endemic disease and protecting the vulnerable.  But he did state that the North East and North West of England are seeing the most concerning rates of the Omicron iant. However, he added: It doesnapost sound all doom and gloom, what we are seeing from hospital admissions is that stays in hospital do appear to be on average shorter, which is good news, symptoms appear to be a little bit milder, so this what we are seeing consistently with the Omicron iant. His comments come after the Prime Minister told a Downing Street press conference this week that England had a chance to ride out this Omicron wave without shutting down our country.  On Friday, the UK reported , daily coronavirus cases and another  deaths. The government say there are , people in hospital with coronavirus as of the last count. Of those,  of whom are in ventilation beds. The R rate has increased and is now estimated to be between . and ., according to the latest figures. Just over  million people have now had a third vaccine, stats show. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.However, health secretary Sajid Javid says the NHS is facing a rocky few weeks ahead as it contends with a wave of Omicron cases.He said: The best thing people can do is get their booster jab. We know now that Omicron is less severe… and we certainly know that once you get boosted that your chance of hospitalisation, our latest analysis shows, is almost % less than it was with Delta. news uk-news dog-compared-peaky-blinders-tommy-"Family in stitches as dog looks like The Office character in hatByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Jan | commentsA Westie cross has been told he could have been an extra in several well known TV series after his owner bought him a novelty accessory. Shannon Kennedy bought the West Highland terrier cross pug, called Albie, a doggy flat cap, and his fans think he should star in the next season of Peaky Blinders. The -year-old, from Newcastle, thought the dog looked like Jim Halpert, the fictional character played by John Krasinski in the US version of The Office, asking followers: “Why does he look like Jim Halpert ”The video caption read: “We got Albie a flat cap for Christmas. He can now match his dads for walks.” Albie could be seen sitting beneath the Christmas tree wearing his newest accessory - which was from BM - while having his photo taken. Followers described Albie as a distinguished gentleman, while suggesting that he could be Tommy Shelby’s doggo’ in Peaky Blinders. Another suggested: “He could be an extra for Still Game,” the long-running Scottish sitcom from . “The most northern dog ever, love it,” one added.Albie isn’t the only pampered pup to have his own fashion staples - in fact, one woman has spent nearly £, on wardrobe accessories for her dog. We know our dogs have quirky personalities, but have you ever thought it might be down to the stars  Just like us, our pups also have their own star signs, and their traits and personalities may very well be affected by them.Feeling intrigued  Discover your dog’s star sign and what it means on our sister site TeamDogsapos Astrology Chart.The dachshund, called Biscuit, owns  pairs of shoes and  pairs of sunglasses, and poses for pictures which are shared with his , Instagram followers.The five-year-old dog, from Piatra Neamț, in Romania, also has a whole wardrobe of colour coordinated clothes with matching hats, wigs and collars. He has more shoes than his owner Lavi Roz and her fiancé put together – with Lavi having  pairs and her fiancé with . The stylish dog even has a pair of Crocs with Swarovski crystals on them.Another couple, Lauren Knight, , and Ryan Carroll, , spend more than £ on their pomeranians, Milo and Mimi, this Christmas.The pair from Ashford, Kent, wanted to make sure they were kitted out in the latest designer gear for the festive season, including £ engraved Louis Vuitton collars. title: family 13 rented 8 bed
story: Family-of- in rented -bed house fear being homeless as council plans to evict themClford Westfall and Clair Pattersons family is now living in fear that they could be torn apart, after Bradford Council told them they must leave their home of two-and-a-half yearsClford Westfall and Clair Patterson live with their nine children, as well as Clair’s brother and Clford’s brother Image: Huddersfield ExaminerByKristian Johnson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA family-of- living in a huge eight-bedroom house are worried they may be left homeless after being handed an eviction notice from their local council. Clford Westfall and Clair Patterson live in Bradford, Yorkshire, with their nine children, as well as Clair’s brother and Clford’s brother, both of whom need extra support. But the family is now living in fear that they could be torn apart, after Bradford Council told them they must leave their home of two-and-a-half years by January . They even fear they could be forced to move into a hostel,they are unable to find another property by the deadline. Clford, , told Yorkshire Live that all they wanted was to be together as a family. The couple pay £, a month for the privately-rented property in Green Head Road and are desperate to remain in the area.Do you think the council should help this family  Share your view in the comments section below Their seven youngest children all go to school in Keighley and the family business, a toy shop in the town centre, is just a mile away. Clair said: If we lived where, it would be physically impossible for me to get seven kids to four dferent schools and then get to work. It just wouldnapost happen.” However, an extension to the property, built by the landlord, breaches planning regulations. The works exceeded the agreed dimensions and the house is now deemed too tall. Three separate retrospective planning applications and an appeal to the governmentaposs planning inspector have all failed. It led to the council obtaining a compulsory purchase order on the property. Clford, Clair and their family were initially told to move out by January . After Clford and Clair were told to leave, they said they asked for help from the council to find somewhere  to live after struggling to find anywhere suitable. There is nothing on the market for a family of our size, said Clford. We used to live in a three-bedroom house a few years ago. We were so happy, even though it was so small, but it just wasn’t big enough.  Since we have been in this big house, we have never been secure or comfortable. The council say they can’t put us in a four or five-bedroom house, because it would be overcrowded, but we need to be together. The couple say they have even asked whether they could have two homes knocked through into one. We’re not trying to be money-grabbers, said Clford. We’re completely willing to pay our way. We pay £, a month in rent. We pay £ a month council tax, we pay all the bills on our house. We don’t want a big house and for it to be cheap. We will pay. We just want to be together. Shortly after YorkshireLive approached Bradford Council for a comment, the local authority said it was trying to extend the deadline beyond January , but this is yet to be formally approved. A spokesperson added the council will continue to support the family throughout the process and that it is exploring the possibility of providing two accommodation units adjacent or in close proximity to each other. But Clford and Clair claim they have been told their family could be moved into a hostel. When they said that, I thought: ‘Is that for real ’ said Clford. “What’s one foot or two feet compared to making a family homeless  If we had to [leave Keighley] we’d do it. But a hostel  It just can’t happen. It wouldn’t work. The couple have one child together, but have custody for their eight children from previous relationships. The youngest is just two-years-old, while the oldest is . Local councillor Mohsin Hussain has tried to push the council to provide more help for the family. It is very dficult to find another property of this size, but I have said to the council that we need to find another property for Clford and his family to move into - or to extend the deadline,” he said. The council is not in the wrong on this, but there needs to be support from the council and from the housing associations for Clford and his family.” However, the family, who spent Christmas with the deadline looming large over their heads, are still no closer to finding somewhere  to live. The couple claim they pay their rent to Jigsaw Property Services. However, a spokesperson for the letting agent said they didn’t let the property out anymore. In a statement, a spokesperson for Bradford Council said: The breach that Mr Westfall appears to be referring to relates to planning permission rather than building regulations. This was obtained by the owner of the property in  to extend the house however, the actual works carried out went beyond that approved resulting in an unauthorised increase in the overall height of the property. Three separate retrospective planning applications for an increase in the roof height have been submitted since the works were undertaken. These applications were all refused and an appeal to the governmentaposs planning inspector by the owner challenging the decision was dismissed on May , . In view of this and as the owner failed to recty the breach, an enforcement notice was issued requiring them to carry out the work in accordance with the approved planning permission or demolish the unauthorised works. No appeal was submitted against the enforcement notice and therefore it should have been complied with by August , . With regard to rehousing Mr Westfall and his family, Mr Westfall and his family have been assessed by the Local Authority’s Housing Options Service in accordance with the Homelessness Reduction Act . The Housing Options Officer is currently exploring suitable rehousing options in the private and social housing sectors. This also includes providing two accommodation units adjacent or in close proximity to each other. Should Mr Westfall become homeless before the eviction deadline, the Local Authority will have a statutory duty to offer temporary accommodation with one of our commissioned providers. The temporary accommodation offer,needed, will be in the same location. The Local Authority will continue to support Mr Westfall and his family during this rehousing process. The council is currently in the process of preparing legal documentation to extend the current deadline of January ,  to allow additional time to source suitable housing options for Mr Westfall and his family. He will be in receipt of this documentation within the next seven days. title: first man seek date through
story: First man to seek a date through billboard advert lts the lid on his love leWith a new man going viral this week in his bid to find a we through a billboard ad, the person who first introduced the trend has revealed what happened after his experimentMark Rofe paid £ for a -foot high and -foot wide billboard to find love Image: Jam PressByAlmara Abgarian:,  Jan The first man known to have sought a date through a billboard ad has lted the lid on his love le, revealing that the ad sadly didn’t lead him to true love. With a new man going viral this week in his bid to find a we through a billboard ad, the person who first introduced the trend has revealed what happened after his experiment – and what he thinks of the copycats.In February , Mark Rofe, , from Sheffield, paid £ for a -foot high and -foot wide billboard to find love. Since then, many others have followed in his footsteps. The latest lovelorn fella isMuhammad Malik , , who has erected ads in London and Birmingham with the tongue-in-cheek caption “save me from an arranged marriage”.“There have been several of these types of billboards since I did mine, and I’m sure there will be plenty more to come too,” Mark said. “I’m always happy to see them when they are done for genuine reasons, and Malik’s does appear to be genuine.  It takes balls to do something like this, so I have a lot of respect for that alone. “I hope it works out for him. I am sure there was perhaps some inspiration taken from the billboard I did, andthat is the case when Malik finds his we from it, I hope I at least get an invite to the wedding.” With Valentineaposs Day fast approaching back in , Mark had chosen to take drastic action in his hunt for a partner. He bought the m high and m wide billboard to advertise himself in Manchester city centre and had  applicants in just  hours. Speaking of the unusual stunt, Mark said he had over , requests and did eventually end up in a relationship. However, he said he didnapost find love from the ad. Now in a new relationship with someone he met in person, he admits he might approach it dferently in hindsight – especially as his new girlfriend told him she saw the ad but would never have considered applying because she thought he looked too desperate. Mark, who is the founder ofChristmastrees , said: “I don’t regret doing the billboard, but it comes with challenges and pressures that I hadn’t considered or foreseen.“The media attention and ‘going viral’ is a double-edged sword, it’s helpful for getting the word out, but on the other hand it was incredibly overwhelming. “It all became a little too much, to the point where, looking back, I probably wasn’t in the right frame of mind to be dating just after I did the billboard. “There are other pressures too, you can’t date everyone – or marry everyone, in Malik’s case – so you’re going to reject a lot of people. I was conscious of the fact that it takes courage to apply to date someone from a billboard ad, and I didn’t want anyone to come away from it feeling rejected or disappointed.  “Then there’s the other additional pressure of, whatI put up this billboard, and then I still don’t find someone ” Two years on, Mark also has some advice for what he thinks others need to do to make something like this successful. Details are very important, even down to the font. He added: “Use comic sans, it is the font of love, so I was disappointed to see that Malik hadn’t used it. “Be specic in what you are looking for. I didn’t specy my sexuality , and at one point half my applications were from men. “Have a thick skin, the internet can be a harsh place so be prepared to be called all sorts of things.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON LoveMarriageViralSexuality" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. This may include adverts from us and rd parties based on our understanding. You can unsubscribe at any time. title: five lockdown demands experts curb
story: Five lockdown demands from experts to curb Omicrons overwhelming riseThe Independent Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesgroup says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitorsIndie Sage are making further recommendations to help curb the spread of the Omicron iant Image: Getty ImagesByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan  group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" group says these measures should be brought in to last at least until the end of February including revising the list of Covid symptoms and ensuring schools have CO monitors" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _UK-In-Fth-Week-Of-Coronavirus-Lockdown.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsFive measures should come into force to slow the spread of the Omicron Covid- iant, the Independent Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesgroup has urged.In a briefing today, Independent Sage they should be brought in to last at least until the end of February.These measures include working from home where possible, providing CO monitors and ensuring adequate ventilation in all classrooms, revising the list of symptoms of Covid- to reflect those associated with Omicron, requiring people to wear high-quality masksin indoor public spaces and providing them for free, and to provide adequate sick pay for those unwell with Covid.Got a story  Email webnews@mirror  The group of about  scientists work together to provide independent scientic advice on the Covid- pandemic. Their recommendations comes as England has reported more than three million Covid cases since December  - with more than one million logged just last week alone.The independent scientists are warning that these alarming figures are almost certainly an underestimate andmeasures were brought in last month it could have helped avert the current NHS crisis.Furthermore, ONS data published this week has revealed that an estimated .million people in the UK - or two per cent of the population - are experiencing long Covid as of December . Other worrying figures have also found that hospitalisations in children under  have trebled since the start of December.Todayaposs announcement from Sage comes as Boris Johnson also confirmed that no further lockdown restrictions would be introduced, but Plan B measures would remain in place for a further three weeks.  Five measures recommended by SAGE  Working from home where possible until the end of February Those in England who can work from home are recommended to, according to current Plan B measures that came into force on December . Plan B measures are still in place and will next be reviewed on January . Mr Johnson told MPs on Wednesday: In response to the latest data the cabinet agreed this morning that we should stick with Plan B for another three weeks with a further review before the regulations expire on  January. This means it could possibly be scrapped by the end of the monththey are not extended again.  Providing CO monitors and ensuring adequate ventilation air filtration in all classrooms This week it was reported that schools are teetering on the edge as more than a third of heads reported staff absence levels of over  per cent due to Covid on the first day of term. A snap survey by the NAHT union found the majorityhad pupils absent due to Covid, while nearly a thirdreported over  per cent of children were out of class because of the virus. In a bid to help stop the spread of Covid- in schools, the Department of Education announced plans to deliver , CO monitors to all state schools.  A poll by the NASUWT teachers union this week foundof the nearly , teachers who responded said they do not have access to a CO monitor in their classroom. From January , the government has said face coverings are recommended in schools with pupils in year  and above. It goes on to say they should be worn in most classrooms, and by pupils, students, staff and adult visitors when moving around buildings.  Revising the list of symptoms of Covid- The NHS website still lists the main symptoms of Covid as a fever, a new cough and the loss of taste or smell. The symptoms that have been associated with the Omicron iant have dfered with many reporting a runny nose, headache, fatigue, sneezing and a sore throat. Professor Tim Spector, the scientist behind symptom tracker app Zoe, described the symptoms of Omicron as being more similar to that of a common cold. This means itaposs much easier to missyouaposre infected with Omicron, with Prof. Spector warning anyone with cold-like symptoms to take a Covid test to make sure.   Requiring high-quality masks for indoor public spaces New rules brought into force last month required anyone aged  or over to wear a face mask to enter a wide range of indoor venues including public transport. FFP masks are considered to be highly-effective face coverings. Many countries in Europe, including Austria, require these specic masks to be worn in public spaces. Independent Sage is recommending the UK government follows suit and requires this specic grade of mask for indoor public spaces as well as providing them for free to households.  Adequate sick pay for those unwell with Covid- From December,  sick pay rules wee being temporarily relaxed to help free up GPs for the booster rollout, meaning workers won’t need to see their doctorthey are unwell over the Christmas period. Under previous rules, workers who are unwell need to show their employer a GP-signed sick note after seven days to receive statutory sick pay or benefit payments. However, this was relaxed to  days – meaning you won’t need proof until almost a month after you fall ill. Anyone in work who goes off sick wonapost be asked for one until after  days of sickness, which includes non-working days. However, this rule is currently in place until January , . After that, the rules willto the normal seven day period. title: healthy dad vowed covid jab
story: Healthy dad vowed to get Covid jab as soon as I can before dying from virusDad-of-three Stephen Doyle, , passed away on January ,  - having sent a text message saying he regretted not getting the jab. He said he had been influenced by things hed read on social mediaStephen told loved ones he would get the jab as soon as he left hospital before sadly dying from the virus Image: BCUHB WALES NEWS SERVICEByJaymelouise Hudspith:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments An unvaccinated dad sent a heartbreaking message to the mother of his children as he lay dying of Covid in a hospital bed.Stephen Doyle, , was fit and healthy before he fell ill with the virus and was rushed to hospital over Christmas, his family said. The dad-of-three passed away on January ,  - after sending a text message saying he regretted not getting the jab.His cousin Michelle Pierce, a nurse practitioner at LlandudnoHospital, spoke on behalf of the family. She said they wanted people to realise coronavirus was affecting younger, healthy people who haven’t been vaccinated – and their families too, reports North Wales Live. Michelle, , said: “When Stephen was in hospital he texted his former partner Nichola and said: ‘I’m getting the jabs as soon as I can’. “He said he never wanted to go through this again. Sadly, he never got the chance to get vaccinated. It was too late for him. “He was against the vaccination before he went in and I would say he was influenced by all the talk on social media. “He had no underlying health conditions. He was fit and healthy.” The former docker, who was working as a dispatch supervisor at the time of his death, had already been in hospital because of Covid but was discharged with antibiotics in mid-December. Michelle said: “We don’t know whether he discharged himself or not but he was self-isolating. His ex-partner Nichola went to see him on December  and found him very unwell.” She called  immediately and Stephen was readmitted to hospital with breathing dficulties and very low oxygen levels in his blood. Within  hours he was moved to the hospital’s intensive therapy unitand the decision to put him on a ventilation machine, to take over his breathing, was taken on Christmas Day. The family say he also had a Deep Vein Thrombosisin his leg, which was concerning the medical team. Michelle: “Coming up to New Year the medical staff were quite positive and they were trying to get him off ventilation but his body was fighting it and they had to stop. He still needed mechanical ventilation to keep him breathing. “We got the call on January  to say his condition had deteriorated.” Doctors told the family Stephen had developed bilateral pneumothorax, which means both lungs had collapsed. Clinicians had to insert four drains into his chest to help him breathe. Lungs in Covid patients can become less flexible which means more pressure is needed to ventilate them. This can result in a collapsed lung. Sadly, in Stephen’s case both failed. Michelle: “The medical team at Warrington Hospital called us in and explained they were running out of options. “On January  they told the family there was nothing they could do. So the decision was taken to withdraw the treatment.” Michelle said Stephens’s mum Janet, sister Nicola and his former partner want people to understand Covid- was not just affecting the vulnerable. She added: “People need to know this is happening to healthy people. If we can save one person by making them get their vaccinations, it’s worth telling our story. “He was just a funny guy. He liked to make people laugh and was always up for laugh. He loved spending time with his kids and making them all happy.” Michelle, who also lost her unvaccinated father-in-law to Covid, revealed the whole family is “devastated and numb, angry and frustrated” – and feel their heartache could have been avoided.  “Stephen’s mum, my auntie, doesn’t want anyone to go through what we are going through,” she said. “A lot of people don’t need to go through this, do they  They should just get vaccinated. “All the people who we know, who were vaccinated but caught Covid, didn’t have severe symptoms. People believe things with no evidence. “Please go out and get vaccinated and prevent your family going through what we as a family are going through – it could be avoided.” Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board’s executive medical director, Dr Nick Lyons said: “I can only offer condolences to Michelle and her family for their sad loss. “I also want to salute their courage in thinking of others so soon after losing a loved one. “They are of course absolutely right - getting a full course of Covid vaccinations is by far the best way of protecting your health during the pandemic.“I would urge people to listen to their story and make arrangements to be vaccinated now, by going to our dedicated vaccination page at: COVID- Vaccinations - Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board nhs.wales”Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON New YearChristmasHospitalsTherapyCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
